item.title: ReplicaSets
item.description: Get Replica Sets kubectl get replicaset kubectl get rs Get single replica set kubectl describe replicaset rs_name Imperative Scale replica set ad-hoc kubectl scale --replicas=6 replicaset rs_name Imperative Destroy replica set kubectl delete replicaset rs_name

item.title: Pods
item.description: Imperative Run pod ad-hoc kubectl run pod_name --image image_name Get all pods kubectl get pods kubectl get pods -o wide # Adds more info like ip Get single pod kubectl describe pod pod_name Imperative Destroy pod kubectl delete pod pod_name

item.title: Deployments
item.description: See rollout status (following logs) kubectl rollout status deployments/d_name See revision history kubectl rollout history deployments/d_name Imperative Rollback to previous revision kubectl rollout undo deployments/d_name Imperative Change deployment image ad-hoc kubectl set image deployments/d_name cont_name=image

item.title: General
item.description: Imperative vs Declarative management commands In K8s, there is three paradigms to manage general resources: Imperative approach with commands: Using kubectl commands like run, create, edit, expose, scale to perform operations Imperative approach using a configuration file: Using kubectl commands like create, replace and delete with -f options Declarative approach using a configuration file: Using kubectl apply -f kubectl apply In general, due to best practices like maintainability, repeatability and documentation, the declarative approach (Using kubectl apply is preferred).
